'Plague' is a deadly infectious disease that is caused by the enterobacteria
[[Yersinia pestis]], named after the French-Swiss bacteriologist Alexandre
Yersin. Primarily carried by rodents (most notably rats) and spread to humans
via fleas, the disease is notorious throughout history, due to the unrivaled
scale of death and devastation it brought. Until June 2007, plague was one of
the three epidemic diseases specifically reportable to the World Health
Organization (the two other ones were cholera and yellow fever). [WHO IHR
Brief No. 2. Notification and other reporting requirements under the IHR (2005).
http://www.who.int/ihr/ihr_brief_no_2_en.pdf]

Depending on lung infection, or sanitary conditions, plague also can be spread
in the air, by direct contact, or by contaminated undercooked food or materials.
The symptoms of plague depend on the concentrated areas of infection in each
person: such as bubonic plague in lymph nodes, septicemic plague in blood
vessels, pneumonic plague in lungs, and so on. It is treatable if detected
early. Plague is still endemic in some parts of the world.
